thread.title: "Pan" joins list of Hollywood box office disasters
thread.title_full: "Pan" joins list of Hollywood box office disasters - Houston Chronicle

author: chron.com
title: "Pan" joins list of Hollywood box office disasters
text:
Photo: Warners Bros. Image 1 of / 24 24 Pan (2015) Budget: $150 million Box Office: $15.5 million
Stars: Hugh Jackman, Rooney Mara, Levi Miller
Photo: Warners Bros. Pan (2015) Budget:� $150 million Box Office:� $15.5... Image 2 of 24 Heaven's Gate (1980) Budget: $44 million Box Office: $3.5 million
Stars: Kris Kristofferson, Christopher Walken
It might not come close to matching some of the epic losses on the list, but director Michael Cimino's Western starring Kris Kristofferson and Christopher Walken is one of cinema's most famous flops. The $44 million film made only $3.5 million domestically and effectively destroyed the estimable United Artists.
Source: Newstimes
Photo: Archive Photos, Getty Images Heaven's Gate (1980) Budget: $44 million Box Office: $3.5... Image 3 of 24 Town & Country (2001) Budget: $90 million Box Office: $10.3 million
Stars: Warren Beatty, Diane Keaton, Goldie Hawn
Somehow this no-frills Warren Beatty, Diane Keaton and Goldie Hawn romantic comedy cost $90 million to produce, and earned $10.3 million worldwide. Suddenly Beatty's 1987 "Ishtar" embarrassment didn't look so bad.
Town & Country (2001) Budget:� $90 million Box... Image 4 of 24 How Do You Know (2010) Budget: $98 million Box Office: $10 million
Stars: Reese Witherspoon, Jack Nicholson, Owen Wilson and Paul Rudd
Having not learned any lessons from "Town & Country's" out of control budget, writer-director James L. Brooks made this romantic triangle comedy, starring Reese Witherspoon, Jack Nicholson, Owen Wilson and Paul Rudd, for $120 million. It went on to gross only $48.7 million worldwide.
Photo: David James, HO How Do You Know (2010) Budget:� $98 million Box Office:� $10... Image 5 of 24 Cutthroat Island (1995) Budget: $120 million Box Office: $48.7 million
Stars: Geena Davis, Matthew Modine
Geena Davis starred alongside Matthew Modine in this pirate adventure, directed by her then-husband Renny Harlin, as a woman seeking buried treasure and vengeance. The $98 million MGM film made only $10 million domestically and for years was considered the biggest money-loser ever.
Photo: Archive Photos, Getty Images Cutthroat Island (1995) Budget:� $120 million Box... Image 6 of 24 The Adventures of Pluto Nash (2002) Budget: $100 million Box Office: $61.7 million
Stars: Eddie Murphy
Warner Bros. sat on this $100 million Eddie Murphy space comedy for two years before finally pushing it out to theaters. The result? A worldwide sum of $7.1 million.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash (2002) Budget:� $100 million Box... Image 7 of 24 The 13th Warrior (1999) Budget: $160 million Box Office: $61.7 million
Stars: Antonio Banderas
This John McTiernan-directed 10th century Viking saga starring Antonio Banderas cost a whopping $160 million to make, bringing in only $61.7 million worldwide.
The 13th Warrior (1999) Budget:� $160 million Box... Image 8 of 24 Mars Needs Moms (2011) Budget: $150 million Box Office: $39 million
Stars: Seth Green, Joan Cusack
This already forgotten, $150 million CG-animated disaster featured the voices of Seth Green and Joan Cusack, and netted only $39 million worldwide.
Mars Needs Moms (2011) Budget:� $150 million Box Office:� $39... Image 9 of 24 47 Ronin (2013) Budget: $175 to $225 million Loss: $175 million
Stars: Keanu Reeves
With a budget that's been reported to be in the $175 to $225 million-range, Keanu Reeves' samurai epic was a flop before audiences had the chance to decide for themselves. Universal let the stinker sit on the shelf for a year, reporting a $175 million loss before the film even hit theaters.
47 Ronin (2013) Budget:� $175 to $225 million Loss:� $175... Image 10 of 24 The Lone Ranger (2013) Budget: $215 million Loss: $160 million to $190 million
Stars: Johnny Depp, Armie Hammer
After spinning box office gold with the "Pirates of the Caribbean" franchise, director Gore Verbinski, producer Jerry Bruckheimer and star Johnny Depp tried their hand at a $215 million take on "The Lone Ranger." The film, which co-starred Armie Hammer, grossed $89 million domestically and $260.5 million worldwide, but Disney still prepped shareholders for a $160 to $190 million loss.
Photo: Peter Mountain, Associated Press The Lone Ranger (2013) Budget:� $215 million Loss:� $160... Image 11 of 24 John Carter (2012) Budget: $250 million to $275 million Loss: $200 million
Stars: Taylor Kitsch
The century-old story may have directly inspired some of modern sci-fi's biggest hits (hello, "Star Wars"), that didn't seem to matter much to anyone in the end. Disney poured a reported $250 to $275 million into producing the film, resting it all on the broad shoulders of small screen star Taylor Kitsch. "John Carter" opened to only $30.2 million, and the studio took a $200 million write-down while it was still in theaters.
Photo: Frank Connor John Carter (2012) Budget:� $250 million to $275... Image 12 of 24 Either being a financial bust or having terrible reviews, see what films were the worst of the summer 2015.
Photo: Ben Rothstein, HONS Either being a financial bust or having terrible reviews, see what... Image 13 of 24 The Man from U.N.C.L.E Budget: $75 million Box Office: $86.4 million Rotten Tomatoes: 67 percent RT Audience Score: 80 percent
Despite its financial standing, this action comedy spy film has been generally well-received.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Daniel Smith, HO The Man from U.N.C.L.E Budget: �$75 million Box... Image 14 of 24 Tomorrowland Budget: $190 million Box Office: $208.3 million Rotten Tomatoes: 50 percent RT Audience Score: 53 percent
Having directed Ratatouille and The Incredible, Brad Bird's Tomorrowland failed to woo audience.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Handout, HO Tomorrowland Budget: �$190 million Box Office:� $208.3... Image 15 of 24 Entourage Budget: $27.5 million Box Office: $44.6 million Rotten Tomatoes: 32 percent RT Audience Score: 68 percent
Just making double in production costs, Entourage did decently.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: HANDOUT, STR Entourage Budget: �$27.5 million Box Office:� $44.6... Image 16 of 24 Pixels (2015) Budget: $88 million Box Office: $94.6 million Rotten Tomatoes: 17 percent RT Audience Score: 55 percent
Based on the 2010 French short film , Adam Sandler continues his streak of poorly received movies.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Courtesy Sony Pictures, HONS Pixels (2015) Budget: �$88 million Box Office:� $94.6... Image 17 of 24 Hitman: Agent 47 Budget: $35 million Box Office: $63.5 million Rotten Tomatoes: 7 percent RT Audience Score: 49 percent
Based on the Hitman video-game franchise, this was a hit and miss.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Reiner Bajo/20th Century Fox, HO Hitman: Agent 47 Budget: �$35 million Box Office:� $63.5... Image 18 of 24 Sinister 2 Budget: $10 million Box Office: $28.4 million Rotten Tomatoes: 13 percent RT Audience Score: 35 percent
Not being able to hit the mark with viewers, Sinister 2 was still able to make a profit.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Elizabeth Morris/Focus Features, HO Sinister 2 Budget: �$10 million Box Office:� $28.4... Image 19 of 24 Aloha Budget: $37 million Box Office: $26.3 million Rotten Tomatoes: 19 percent RT Audience Score: 32 percent
Not even Bradley Cooper, Emma Stone and Bill Murray could save this romantic comedy.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Neal Preston, HONS Aloha Budget: �$37 million Box Office:� $26.3 million Rotten... Image 20 of 24 The Gallows Budget: $100,000 Box Office: $38.1 million Rotten Tomatoes: 16 percent RT Audience Score: 27 percent
Similar to Paranormal Activity (2007) in terms of financial success and style, The Gallows was not as well received as it horror counter part.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Handout, HO The Gallows Budget: �$100,000 Box Office:� $38.1... Image 21 of 24 Hot Pursuit Budget: $35 million Box Office: $51.4 million Rotten Tomatoes: 8 percent RT Audience Score: 37 percent
Coming out during the same time period as Avengers: Age of Ultron , Reese Witherspoon and Sofia Vergara were not enough to beat Captain America and the Avengers.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: HANDOUT, STR Hot Pursuit Budget: �$35 million� Box Office:� $51.4... Image 22 of 24 Fantastic 4 (2015) Budget: $120 million Box Office: $155.9 million Rotten Tomatoes: 9 percent RT Audience Score: 21 percent
The third superhero movie of the summer, Fantastic Four was not able to bask in the same glory as its Marvel Studios competition.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Courtesy Twentieth Century Fox, HONS Fantastic 4 (2015) Budget: �$120 million Box Office:� $155.9... Image 23 of 24 We Are Your Friends Budget: $6 million Box Office: $3.7 million Rotten Tomatoes: 42 percent RT Audience Score: 47 percent
With the fourth worst opening weekend of all time , We Are your friends is one of the worst films of the summer.
Source: Box Office Mojo
Photo: Tony Rivetti Jr. SMPSP, HONS We Are Your Friends Budget: $6 million Box Office: $3.7 million Rotten... Image 24 of 24 "Pan" joins list of Hollywood box office disasters 1 / 24 Back to Gallery LOS ANGELES (AP) — "Pan" walked the plank this weekend and it didn't go well.
Warner Bros.' $150 million live-action Peter Pan origin story captured a dismal $15.5 million from North American theaters, and its international prospects don't look much more promising. The film earned only $20.5 million from 52 markets.
Unlike Disney's largely profitable foray into live-action fairy tale adaptations, "Pan, "starring Hugh Jackman, Rooney Mara and newcomer Levi Miller, might find Warner Bros. taking a write-down for their losses. Only time and the promise of an Oct. 22 China opening will seal "Pan's" ultimate fate, but it already has the dubious distinction of being one of 2015's biggest bombs, up there with Disney's "Tomorrowland" and Fox's "Fantastic Four."
In honor of the rare, fascinating spectacle of the box office bomb, here are some of Hollywood's most infamous financial catastrophes.
